thread.title: Humana Inc. stock dive started after Hillary Clinton comment on health insurers
thread.title_full: Humana Inc. stock dive started after Hillary Clinton comment on health insurers

author: courier-journal.com
title: Humana Inc. stock dive started after Hillary Clinton comment on health insurers
text:
Humana's stock has dropped $20 per share in two days, a free fall that began shortly after reports emerged Wednesday that Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton supports tough scrutiny for proposed health insurer consolidations.
Louisville-based Humana's stock price had been hovering around $185 in recent months. But shortly after Clinton said she has "serious concerns" about health insurer Aetna's plan to acquire Humana and Anthem's proposal to buy Cigna, Humana's share price began a dip.
By the market close on Thursday, the Louisville-based company's share price hit $165.11, a decline of $12.04 over the prior day. At one point Thursday, the price fell to $162.21.
Aetna's price also fell nearly $5 per share on Thursday, to $103.41.
Clinton said in a statement Wednesday that "as we see more consolidation in health care, among both providers and insurers, I'm worried that the balance of power is moving too far away from consumers. ... These mergers should be scrutinized very closely with an eye to preventing the undue concentration that they appear to create."
THE COURIER-JOURNAL
Humana shareholders sue to block Aetna deal
Clinton is leading the race for the party's nomination and previously criticized the pharmaceutical industry for "price gouging," a comment sure to catch the attention of senior voters. She indicated she'd cap out-of-pocket prescription costs at $250 a month.
Aetna and Humana shareholders on Monday overwhelmingly backed a proposal for Hartford, Conn.-based Aetna to buy Humana for $37 billion, a deal announced last July. Within weeks, Anthem made a successful bid to buy Cigna for $48 billion. Both deals must get the green light from federal regulators and state insurance agencies.
If the purchases are OK'd, three companies would dominate the U.S. health insurance market -- Anthem, United Health and Aetna -- roughly in order of size.
Many consumer advocates, as well as doctors and hospital groups, have urged federal regulators now reviewing the acquisitions to look closely at the impact on consumers when competition is reduced dramatically in thousands of U.S. markets.
In the Aetna-Humana deal, Aetna executives have said they have been "conservative" in planning for divestitures in areas where the companies overlap significantly, but they've expressed confidence that the transaction will go through, probably in the second half of 2016.
Still, the timing of next year's election in November and regulators' review wrapping up next year may raise concerns for investors.
Clinton didn't pull punches: "As we see more consolidation in health care, among both providers and insurers, I'm worried that the balance of power is moving too far away from consumers," she said in a statement.
Reporter Grace Schneider can be reached at 502-582-4082 or by email, gschneider@courier-journal.com.
